title: Tether’s $110 Billion Empire: How They Built It - Reeve Collins, сo-Founder of Tether

rawLines.text: Good morning and welcome to day two of
Proof of Talk. My name is Gareth
Jeninson. I'm the head of multimedia
here at Cointelegraph and this is our
first live stream of the day. I'm I'm
very excited to chat to to Reeve
Collins, a man who's very well known for
co-ounding Tether. And I think we're
just going to start the conversation
there. Um take us back in time. Tell us
about the the Genesis story of Tether,
how you started it, what it was then
versus what it was now. what it is now.
Well, it's definitely quite a story and
it's really really amazing to see where
it's come and uh how it's just laid the
foundation for the entire cryptocurrency
ecosystem and and so just seeing that
come to fruition does make me very
proud. But um yeah, you have to rewind
all the way back to 2013, which is when
I first got into Bitcoin. And uh Brock
Pierce was a good friend of mine and you
know we used to hang out a lot and and I
was just really wanted to dive into
something new and he's like look you got
to buy some Bitcoin. So I just really
started getting into the space in 2013
and then uh a lot of discussions and a
lot of time later and an idea came up
which was putting the dollar on the
blockchain. Okay. Um and back then there
was only about five cryptocurrencies and
so it just the the whole market was
maybe two to three billion dollars. So
it was really small and nent, but the
concept is pretty straightforward. We
had a new way to move money globally,
instantly and for free. Um, the problem
at that point in time was the type of
money we were moving was Bitcoin. So it
was super unfamiliar. It was this new
type of foreign currency based in code
and people just didn't get it. It was
such a small amount of people trading
it. But the blockchain, you know, really
allowed you to do something unique and
different, which was move that money and
confirm those transactions. So the
concept was format dollars, euros, yen
to work on the blockchain. Just create
that bridge, tether it to the dollar.
And so that's how it rolled out. And
then back then, you got to think, we
were the first people to really tokenize
any real world asset. So we tokenized
the dollar. And so we had to build the
technology. And so Craig Sers was part
of um Mastercoin at that time. So he
came on and co-ounded it with us. Yeah.
Sorry about that. Just turned off my
phone. The rule is you have to take the
call. And No, I'm joking.
Um anyways and uh and we really um
utilized Mastercoin which is now Omni to
write messages to the Bitcoin blockchain
and built that tech out and then uh and
really just put that out there and
that's when Bitfinex came in early on
because they're the ones that had the
first use case. So a lot of people
didn't realize okay great it might be
nice to move money around the world but
who needed to do it because they weren't
using the blockchain yet. So the way it
evolved was the exchanges wanted to
settle their order books amongst each
other and then soon after that you know
they also then they started listing it
and then the traders realized oh I can
instead of pulling my money out of the
system I can just put it on the
sidelines but stay in the arena like I
can trade from bit um bitcoin into
tether onchain dollars and then from
there once the traders used it amongst
themselves it rolled into payments yeah
because then they started paying other
people and then this was a slow roll out
it took about you know years and years
for it to really start picking up. Um,
but then the whole world started feeling
the power of it and really Tether itself
as a as a company and an entity really
took off in in 2017 after we were gone.
We sold it uh earlier on um in the ICO
boom and I got to hand it to Paulo and
the team there. I mean they're
extraordinary humans and they've just
done a really fantastic job. So again, I
couldn't be more proud of where it's
ended up. Um, if you are joining us on
the live stream on X or YouTube, please
feel free to drop some questions in for
for Reev if you want to know about the
genesis story of Tether, why you got out
of Tether. It's up to you. We've got him
here. We've got him here on the live
stream. So, fire away with your
questions and uh we will ask them
through the course of this uh
conversation. And let's add some even
more exciting questions about what I'm
doing now, what I've done since, and
where the future's going. There we go.
Yeah, I I do want to probe that very
quickly. um uh the the founding partner
sold tether right in in 2015. Um maybe
my history is a little bit wrong. Why at
the time did you make that decision and
all these years later just considering
how profitable a business is? You know,
is there any lingering regret about
that? Look, hindsight's always 2020, but
we always live our lives and we all do
our best to live our lives with no
regrets. So, I'm extremely proud of of
of where where it's come, what it's
turned into, and and the just the
significant impact it's had on the world
and how it's shifting the future of
finance and how it's lifting people out
of poverty and giving a lot of people a
chance. And that's why also seeing
Tether being um moving its headquarters
El Salvador and focusing on Central and
South America, those are the people that
need it most. So, it's just I mean, it
still gives me chills just to see that
that impact that it's had. So, so it's
amazing. But you have to rewind back to
2015. The market crashed. There was no
business model. You have to realize what
Tether's business model was, right? It's
make money on the float. How much float
was there? Especially back then, none.
And uh and then it evolved into buying
treasuries and other assets to back the
the currency. But the original promise
of Tether, which they still hold true to
this day, is give me a dollar, I put it
in the bank, and I issue a token. So the
elegance of its business model was in
its simplicity. And that concept,
putting a dollar on the blockchain,
moving money globally, instantly for
free, and democratizing access for the
world to dollars, it's just it it was
proven to be a super powerful concept.
Um, so there are no regret regrets.
There's just lots of pride and I'm
excited about building better, bigger,
greater things uh in the future. Yeah, I
mean to think of Tether today, I've met
Paulo many times and uh we've had many
many very interesting conversations
about their approach that it seems like
they stumbled onto the easiest and best
solutions when they started investing in
in Treasury bulls, right? Because it's a
it's a stable yield over a long period
of time, very very low risk, fairly
liquid, and I mean to me it's like once
they figured that out, it seems like
everyone else will want to go and do
that because it's such a smart move. Um,
and it also allows them to generate
profit off a business that would
otherwise, like you said, just take a
dollar and put it in the bank. Um, did
you guys think that was part of the
natural progression? Was it something
you wanted to do back then, uh, invest
in T- bills? Well, actually, it's like
figure out how to how to maximize the
value that we're holding without
compromising the security and the the
backing of the currency. And so, yeah,
those are definitely the natural
progressions. And and what's amazing
about the space now is that it's
evolving. So fast forward 10 plus years
and all these RWAs are coming on chain
very high quality low or very high
quality and low-risk assets that have
decent yield and those types of onchain
assets are going to be utilized as
backing for stable coins. And there will
be decentralized stable coins coming out
because now that treasuries and other
assets are on chain, you don't need a
centralized entity to be the one that
buys your dollar that buys your treasury
and then m then mints the token. So I'm
rolled out a new company called
stable.com stbl.com.
Um, we've been working on it for about
almost a year now and all of the
infrastructure is in place to do exactly
that where the user can buy a treasury
or another high quality RWA and post it
as collateral and mint their own stable
coin. And when they do that, we strip
the interest. We strip the yield into a
separate token. And so the user gets to
keep the yield and then push out the
non-interest bearing stable coin. So
it's not a yield bearing stable coin.
So, it's not a security. Um, so there's
going to be a lot of novel approaches to
how the world utilizes stable coins. And
right now, stable coins are it's the
narrative, right? It's the vibe.
Everyone's trying to create a stable
coin and launch one. And there's a lot
of reasons for it. The biggest one being
the regulatory winds are at our back.
Whereas the for until today, it was
right in our face. So that allows
institutions to really get in and
governments and and the rest of the
world to really get involved and utilize
both blockchain technology and these
types of currencies to make their
businesses better because that's the
entire point of what we're doing, right?
Blockchain technology makes businesses
and transactions more efficient. It
connects the world. However, you need
basically government approval or at
least a path to be able to do that. And
now that's here. I've got a really great
question here. I mean there there's
always been a lot of controversy around
Tether, especially between 2017 and
2020. Rugpull Max in the comments says,
"Rev, how much USDT did you print before
there were any real reserves?" I mean,
this is this is a good chance to talk
about some of the FUD over the years and
and how things actually worked. Look,
all I can comment on is the FUD. It's it
was insane, wasn't it? Just crazy. But
it just goes to show that anyone who's
at the top of anything and doing
something revolutionary and on the
cutting edge is always going to have

they just want to tear you down for no

there's such an easy way to do it now
with online communications and social
media that people just attack and attack
and attack and there was never any
substance to that. And so Tether has
proven over and over and over again that
the backing's there, that the dollars
are there, and that they're rock solid.
And I used to always say, because people
say, "Oh, Tether doesn't hold its peg.
It's lost its peg over here, lost its
peg over there." Those are third party
exchanges. Those are the the supply and
demand on that particular venue. You can
always go to Tether and redeem for the
dollar. Um they're one of the only
companies that does that type of
redemption. Yeah. Um another question
here. Call us ready. Um, uh, Tether,
it's saying you, um, Reeve doesn't work.
I'm no longer with Tether. I don't
represent them. I just admire them. Um,
but yeah. Um, it says Tether's planning
to launch a new coin to comply with US
and and EU laws. Probably not EU yours,
but I've spoken to Paulo and they're
looking at doing a sort of compliant
new, uh, sort of USDT for the the US
market. um would that mean that existing
USDT holders are forced to switch or you
know are unable to use those tokens
going forward? So again, I don't know
the nuances, but I can give you an
opinion from a high level. I'm betting
that they're all completely funible
because the regulatory oversight is
probably really specifically directed at
the where the value where the backing is
held and who the custodians are and what
the type of backing it is. And so that
flavor of Tether that's that has that
regulatory backing can be whitelisted
and sold to US customers, but once it's
in the wild, it's in the wild and I'd
almost guarantee they're going to be
completely funible.
My my next question just a stable coins
in general, Circle went public last last
week like massive massive valuation.
Paulo Paulo went to, you know, uh, New
York for the first time this year and,
uh, you know, he said to me in private
like, "We don't need we we don't want to
be publicly listed. We don't need to be
publicly listed, but it's very telling
that the second biggest stable coin
issuer company is now a publicly listed
company." Do you view that as a a
natural progression of things? And is it
good for the industry that a player like
Circle is is a publicly traded company?
First, I feel it's definitely good for
the industry. What's not good for the
industry is if it stock tanks. Yes. But
it's there's so much hype and so much
pent up demand to get involved in stable
coins because all of retail or all of
the people that really aren't in the
crypto space, they hear about it and
then Circle comes out and so they they
pile in and it really drove the price up
and the fundamentals aren't quite there
to support that level of price. So, as
long as people understand that a lot of
it is market irrationality and it's
excitement, which is really great, but
when the price goes down, it's not a
reflection on the business or the the
capabilities of what stable coins have
to offer. Let's talk a little bit about
life after tether. I mean, um you you
you're one of the the founders of Pi
Protocol, right? You're doing Weii now.
Um how has your approach changed to
working in this industry? And before we
speak about Bitcoin, because I really
want to chat to you about Bitcoin. Sure.
Yeah. So there's been a lot of life
after Tether and a lot of interesting
things. So after bringing the stable
coin to market, the next big thing we
rolled out was the first NFT. So we
really champion like brought to market
and pioneered the NFT before there was
word NFT and that company was called
Block V. We did an ICO and we called
them VAMS like these highly programmable
digital goods because we didn't there
was no word NFT for this but we we
wanted you to be able to uniquely own a
digital object. The challenge with NFTs
is they got a bad rap because they had
this massive runup because everyone's
speculating and gambling on images, but
that's not really the best use case of
NFTs. I still can't stress the
importance of how much NFTs will impact
our lives going forward because
everyone's going to have a wallet. Those
digital wallets are going to be filled
with both tokens and currencies, but
NFTTS because NFTs are going to
represent so many different facets of
our life. So I created an
extraordinarily robust technology
platform um that's still in use today
like Visa and then another company on
top of that Smart Media and then Smart
Media has done a deal with Visa and
Visa's utilizing all of this technology
that BlockV built for their web 3 wallet
in the loyalty space. So that was a big
chapter of my life and one that was also
really exciting and impactful. And then,
you know, and most recently, yeah, I
launched a company called Pi Protocol,
and that's what was rebranded to stable
a few months ago. Um, stable.com because
now there's another like stable that
just came out. But anyways, um, ours is
stbl.com and and and but that's just the
that's the evolution of the stable coin.
It's what I was talking about before.
It's bringing technology that delivers
on the promise of web 3. And what's the
promise of web 3? it's that the users
and the community and the people out
there are the ones that reap the rewards
and the benefits for participating in
whatever service that platform provides.
And and with stable, the users are the
one that reap all the rewards. They're

utilizing it. Um and then in addition,
so right now I'm I'm
creating this ecosystem of companies to

blockchain and of web 3. And the other

another really exciting company. And
it's it's the first ever decentralized
onchain bank. So we call it a DEO bank,
the evolution of the Neo Bank, which is
just an online bank that still uses
legacy rails to a decentralized onchain

fully onchain and it packages all the

and loans, but also allows you access to
DeFi. Yeah. But what's most exciting
about these new types of financial
services is that when you can in a very

in stables and we do the hard stuff in

that level of uh return. It's super
valuable for the end user. So Weii has
built community first and really passing
on all those rewards to the users. Yeah.
Um, this this ties into a question we

And I I would imagine a future where

You are. Um maybe you can answer that

It's because we don't feel the pain. We

on this planet. So the rest of the

this is lifechanging. It really makes a

a web 3 rails. There'll be financial
services. You're going to log into

you're going to have better, quicker,
cheaper services that provide higher

hold dollars or stable coins and you
have a choice. Hold dollars and earn a
half a percent on your checking account.
Hold stable coins just by clicking a
button and earn 8%. you know, it's it's
going to be up to the user. And so then
the use cases and the choices become
pretty obvious of what you're going to
use. And so more and more in the normal

transactions you want to do under the
hood is all going to be run on
blockchain rails because it's more
efficient. Yep. Um there's another

CryptoCap 7398, that's a weird username.
Um, tether's ties with Caner Fitzgerald

again I'm just speaking as an outsider
but I would imagine that Tether has had
not only scrutiny from the SEC but

other countries around the world so I
mean they are probably as squeaky clean

at it I would guess um my my Next

Again, the only detail, the only

if you're a stable coin uh issuer in

So you have to go to smaller banks.
These banks, a lot of them run
fractional reserve systems. You expose

basically said if I don't have to if
that means I don't serve Europe and you

privileged when it comes to payment
systems. whereas developing nations need
uh systems that hold value and we can
transact very quickly. So I think that
adds a little bit more nuance to to that

the conversations I've had with some

kind of helping US dollar hedgemony and
at some stage is that going to become a

to get people to use Bitcoin and maybe

I fundamentally don't believe that

so
I, yeah,
Bitcoin is going to be a store of value

is something that Hellf said was going
to happen like on the second day of the

Um, the second question to that, uh,

Uh, it ties into the security

I in my mind US Tether does it so well

there's always going to be new

And it's healthy. It's healthy

so we put it out there. We're excited

What to to bring it full circle. It's so

cleanText:
Good morning and welcome to day two of Proof of Talk. My name is Gareth Jeninson. I'm the head of multimedia here at COINTELEGRAPH, and this is our first live stream of the day. I'm very excited to chat to Reeve Collins, a man who's very well known for co-founding Tether. And I think we're just going to start the conversation there. Um, take us back in time. Tell us about the genesis story of Tether, how you started it, what it was then versus what it is now. Well, it's definitely quite a story, and it's really, really amazing to see where it's come and how it's just laid the foundation for the entire cryptocurrency ecosystem, and so just seeing that come to fruition does make me very proud. But, um, yeah, you have to rewind all the way back to 2013, which is when I first got into Bitcoin. And Brock Pierce was a good friend of mine, and you know, we used to hang out a lot, and I was just really wanted to dive into something new, and he's like, "Look, you got to buy some Bitcoin." So I just really started getting into the space in 2013, and then a lot of discussions and a lot of time later, an idea came up, which was putting the dollar on the blockchain. Okay. Um, and back then there was only about five cryptocurrencies, and so it just, the whole market was maybe two to three billion dollars. So it was really small and nascent, but the concept is pretty straightforward. We had a new way to move money globally, instantly, and for free. Um, the problem at that point in time was the type of money we were moving was Bitcoin. So it was super unfamiliar. It was this new type of foreign currency based in code, and people just didn't get it. It was such a small amount of people trading it. But the blockchain, you know, really allowed you to do something unique and different, which was move that money and confirm those transactions. So the concept was format dollars, euros, yen to work on the blockchain. Just create that bridge, tether it to the dollar. And so that's how it rolled out.
